description.text: A cutout design for a glass piece that you can put over the heatbed of a Prusa Mendel from Makergear. It has all the holes necessary for the screws plus a cutout to allow the connections and LED.

I have created this part because the Prusa Mendel sold by Makergear has a heated PCB to build on, but it warps when heated. It gives bad prints because the build bed isn't perfectly flat. This piece of glass will be put over the PCB and under a layer of capton tape on which the build will happen. The holes are of two different sizes. 3mm (1/8th inch) and 4.75mm (3/16th inch). The DXF file can be used with a laser cutter to cut both the glass and the wood. Full details and assembly instructions are available here

title: Lady Adventurers! Human Female Fighter, Female Dwarf Cleric, Female Drow Warlock

description.text:
Some adventurers for an upcoming campaign. I modeled and modified them in Blender. Spliced in Cura. Printed with my Printrbot Simple Metal. Will post pics of the prints soon!   
The human fighter is based off of Alanna of Trebond from the series "The Song of the Lioness" by Tamora Pierce.

Print the dwarf on her back with supports.  
Print the fighter laying on her back with supports. If the sword doesn't come out right, model it separately and glue it down. I had to do this unfortunately. The body came out right, so I took a little bit of sculpy, put it where the hands are, covered it with super glue, and then place the sword (just blade and top of hilt) inside. Then after it dried I just molded it a little to make it look right.   
Print the drow standing. She comes with her own supports as Cura couldn't handle such a small object. To remove them get a small exacto blade, heat it over a candle, and just slice them off carefully. Heat for 15 seconds and it gives you a 3 second slicing window before the blade cools down.

remixed_from.title: Criss Cross Laser cut fan grill 40mm

description.text: A lasercut case for the Duet-Controller (http://reprap.org/wiki/Duet) that mounts onto the aluminium extrusions of a kossel. To be made out of 4mm material. Please feel free to share your makes/remixes and leave suggestions for improvements in the comments :)

Cut out of 4mm Material and assemble as shown in the picture. I used CA. Glue one of the 4mm spacer-rings over each one of the 4 mounting holes for the duet and attach the cross-brace to the back in the center using glue. Screw in the Duet using m3 screws. and screw the whole case to the extrusion.
Included are 2 cover-designs. I use the one that is one piece and hold it shut using 2 rubber bands. I am planning on using the 2 part design and turn it into a magnetic hatch by glueing the frame to the case and using the cut out squares ans magnets to somehow attach magnets (That was a bit of a bodged afterthought while standing in front of the lasercutter :P). Mount 2 40mm fans to the cover if necessary.
The square holes are appropriately sized so the nylon mesh does not fall out if the end is tucked in.
However, you might need to make the usb cutout a little bit bigger to fit the usb plug that came with the Duet (or just cut away some of the plastic of the cable as I did). Furthermore, removing the Ethernet-cable requires some tool or untrimmed fingernails to press down the lever. The fan cutouts are remixed from 3dyuval´s criss cross fan grill (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:425789), which I think looks really neat.
Used in an Austin Healey 100/6 to hold a generic (not OEM) flasher unit.

description.text: Previous Owner drilled 2 holes in the rear bumper for an antenna.  The plug snaps into the holes to cover them.

This is a replacement volume knob for a B&K REF 20 A/V preamplifier. My original was loose and I believed the set screws were striped. As it turns out I just didn't have the right Allen wrench (1/16"). In any case once I had the right wrench I still made the knob, mostly to figure out the inserts for future projects. I used 6/32 threaded inserts and 6/32 set screws. The parts and Allen wrenches are all available from Amazon: E-Z Lok Threaded Insert, Brass, Knife Thread, #6-32 Internal Threads, 0.375" Length (http://amzn.com/B0026GUEN4 ) 18-8 Stainless Steel Set Screw, Plain Finish (http://amzn.com/B005A1SXJ4) mini Allen wrenches (http://amzn.com/B003N9B6BC)

I printed with a .2 mm layer height, 30% fill, normal shells, and standard speed.  After the knob was built I screwed in the insert.  I'm sure it would go in easier with the knob on the heated print bed but I didn't try this since it could end up damaging the print bed glass.  After the insert is installed, it's as easy as putting in the set screw and installing on the receiver.

Viel Spaß!

This gadget can dispense glass beads (or any other spherical things) of 3mm diameter one at a time. A video is posted at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LgEwp8v0wIc&feature=em-upload_owner It is made from laser cut 3mm acryllic. It should be possible to scale it to fit bigger beads, but the material thickness should be adjusted accordingly. I have considered adding a springload, but this will be some time in the future. Please let me know in the comments if you manage to do so before me.

The pdf file gives instructions. The purpose of the engraving is to mark the exact place where you should glue the two bead stoppers, and to increase friction for the glue to bind better.  
Parts are assembled with 4mm machine screws.

comments.text: I couldn't find instructions in the PDF which only showed the model design so thought I'd share my experience. The screw type is critical. Using anything smaller than 4 mm will allow too much non-parallel motion of the thumb piece which makes the mechanism clunky/sticky. Install screws through the first plate and two triangular, guiding pieces as the first step (these can also be glued together). When gluing the small pieces for the chute, place them in situ, add glue, then overlay the engraved piece onto the screws and press down to get perfect alignment. I tried gluing them onto the engraved thumb piece ex situ but didn't line them up properly due to the very low tolerance for mis-alignment.

Simular to the Automatic Rubber Band Blaster-32, just bigger holding 72+ rubber bands. It fires ~7 rubber bands per second and can be instantly reloaded by swapping barrels. Slow motion Video: http://youtu.be/YlqbK6L4HVo

I recommend that you first print and build the smaller Automatic Rubber Band Blaster before you build this one. The loading is the same and the assembly is very similar, but you'll have to glue the top and bottom together with plastic glue. I don't have an instructional video for this one, but the wiring/ motor & button connections are the same as in the Automatic Rubber Band Blaster video below. Uses #32 rubber bands Videos:
Reloading: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m4xSol8nA3I
Assembly: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i-P6L7N33EY In addition to the printed parts you will need: 1- Right Angle, Single Sided Geared Motor
1- 2xAA Battery Holder
1- Large, Red Classic Momentary On Switch
1- 7" by 3/8" Dowel
1- 2.5" by 3/8" Dowel
1- Screw Eyes 5/16" Inside Diameter
1- Screw Eyes 1/8" Inside Diameter
1- 5" Two Conductor Insulated Wire
2- 3" Single Conductor Insulated Wire
3- #6x5/8" Screws
2- #4x1" Screws
1- #2x1/4" Screw
1- 4.5' Nylon String Use your own non printable parts or order the kit with the non printable parts online at http://www.shuttlebaylabs.com PS This was part of a KickStarter that I did last summer:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1260445854/automatic-rubber-band-blaster-kit

description.text:
Here's a little handle to turn your bare-ended needle file set into proper tools.

Print with a raft so it stays stable while printing.
The size of those file shafts varies a bit so I've made the handle holes 3mm and drilled out to 3.2mm for a good fit, adding a drop of foaming gorilla glue to keep them in. Alternatively, scale the STL as required. I printed at 15% fill and 2 shells, and if your setup is anything like mine you'll have a neat little musical groove going while it's printing.

description.text: I am still learning how to use my 3D printer and I wanted to try to replicate something and see if it would fit back together the same as the original. I copied all of the measurements from an original RCX backplate and printed up a new one, and it fit perfectly. I didn't bother adding any of the peg holes on the bottom, but someone could add them if they wanted to take the time.

Safety in mind with a touch of steampunk design, this is the base unit that you can add new fittings to using the rivet holes. I'll make some attachments but feel free to go nuts for now. They are very universal fitting my 5 yr old daughter or myself just fine. You'll need to cut your own lens I use Plexy Glass and a laser cutter. Lenses are 45mm diameter.
.5 in elastic can be found at your local crafting supply store in the sewing isle. You can use 3mm PLA for the rivets instead of M3 screws. The eye cups get glued to the glass frames using super glue -- important to do that step before putting the lens in or the fumes might white up. Let dry before wearing or the super fumes will hurt super bad near your eyes. After it is dry you can wear them forever ;)...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WqNxYHWpYko

title: Raspberry Pi 2 or B+ slimline clip case

description.text:
This case is designed to be laser cut from 3mm acrylic. The case is an evolution of my previous B+ case design but 4mm shorter. The tolerances are very close but the design has been successfully
realised, though even the protective plastic covering upsets the slot
sizes enough to cause issues. Using 1/8th inch acrylic does not work with this design! I used 10mm long M2.5 nylon bolts to hold the board to the base with nylon washers underneath the board as spacers. Layer 0 (black) is the through sheet profile cut.
Layer 1 (red) is the connector and slot cutouts
Layer 2 (yellow) is the text The µSD card slot is very fiddly to access This is a working design and has been made by me but I offer no
guarantee that it will work for you. I keep the original design files on [github]( https://github.com/kyllikki/designs)

My steppers have machined pulleys fixed on them so the normal couplings do not fit. These fit perfectly.

My steppers have machined pulleys fixed on them for HTD 3M belt. I cannot seem to get the pulleys off. The pulleys have a length of 14.5mm, but the teeth only go untill 10,5 mm.The pulleys have a diameter of 9.7mm with 11 teeth and a 3mm pitch. You'll need to print both halves twice, the halves are not the same. I could not make them the same because with 11 theeth i needed a mirrored cavity.
Furthermore you will need 8 m4 x 10mm screws and 8 m4 nuts. If you als have steppers with these pulleys you might also like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:51618 , an Y bracket you can use when your belt runs close to your stepper

Like having room temperature (very spreadable) butter available all the time? Me too!
However no one likes butter gone rancid or with off flavors.
The French have a solution in an air tight sealed butter tub.that keeps your room temp butter fresh. Went looking online for one and found they ranged in price from $20. to $40 and up. This inspired my 3D printable version. My version costs about 100 grams of filament.

Material: HIPS or other certified food safe filament.
Raft & supports OFF
Infill 20 to 30%
If you choose to use the text label, I suggest printing it in a different color than the tub. Letters can be glued on using plastic model cement or ABS pipe cement. Spreader material HIPS or other food safe plastic.
raft and supports off
Set to High quality Infill 60%
May need to lightly sand the top of the tapered end smooth. Place butter in the flanged tub, press in firmly with a spoon making sure butter is in full contact with the sides & bottom and has minimum air pockets. (keeps butter from falling out when tub is inverted) Place about 1/2 inch (13mm) of water in the outer cup. The water provides an air tight seal. Invert the inner flanged cup and place in the outer cup. Butter is now safe from air, and floating air borne microbes, It is best to use either distilled water or boiled & cooled water. Change the water every few days.

title: Qi Wireless (Model T513) Charging dock for iPhone 6 Plus

description.text:
This dock was designed for the Model T513 Qi wireless charger.
The charger snaps into the recessed area in front while the charger's cable is fed through from below.
Lay your phone on the dock and it's charging! No more wires.
(You need to have both the charger and the charging receiver) My initials are on the stl file but can be easily removed. The lip the phone is cradled by was designed to accommodate an iphone 6 Plus case. I added some small rubber feet that came with an Arduino micro controller to minimize the dock sliding on the desk.

comments.text:
If you want a much cleaner looking result, try reducing the extrude speed to 5 to 10 mm/sec.
Slowing the extrude speed allows the plastic time to cool resulting in a much cleaner print.
Yes it does take a bit more time to print but I'm sure you will like the results.
Most all small objects will benefit from this adjustment.
Optionally try adding several other small object to print at the same time, again this allows cooling time that results in cleaner prints.

title: Saab 99/900 Turbo Inca Ronal Wheel Insert Centres

description.text:
Replacement Inserts (Centre caps) for the Ronal "Inca" Wheels.  
These replace the hard to find originals, slightly tweaked design to make them more printable but look pretty convincing compared to originals..  
Cap is a separate part to allow FDM printing. May fit other Ronal wheels.
[update] I've now uploaded an optional cap that has Saab lettering in case you don't have stickers available.

Prints in two parts. Just glue the cap on with a suitable adhesive once done.  
Make sure your printer is calibrated or you may end up with something which doesn't fit the hole.  
Cap part benefits from a bit of light sanding to remove steps even at 2mm layer height.  
[Updated]
I've uploaded a Saab logo version of the cap, the stickers are hard to find and don't last very long, the original metal badges are about as rare as the original caps.
The letters are raised, so either do as I have done and print them in silver filament. Then once printed and before painting, lightly coat the raised logo and ring in vaseline or grease. Paint and allow to dry, the paint should be easy to remove from the bits you coated.
Or print it in black...then paint the raised parts in silver paint...best to do this by wetting a flat surface with silver paint and placing the cap on it.

author: digimatic

title: Printrbot Simple fan mount for an actual 40mm fan

description.text:
This is a remix of the-kenny's fan mount. I remixed it to work with a 40
mm fan. The difference from the original is that the mounting holes on
this one are 30mm apart and will fit the 40mm fan that came with the
printrbot simple 1310. The printrbot in the picture is the original 1310 with upgraded
aluminum extruder, bed plate, and x/y axis modifications. Update: I added a second file (FANMOUNTwCutOut) that doesn't
block airflow through the top of the fan, both files will work, but I
recommend the latest one.

They both work, but you only need one of these files, either
FANMOUNT or FANMOUNTwCutOut. I like the cutout version better. I printed this in PLA with .2mm layers, 50% infill and support. It's friction fit to the printer. While installing, I angled it to point at the
print head, see the picture.

a keychain for your love. Inspired by; http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:672318

Just a combo of support and bracket mounts for a Nema 17 Stepper. I use one of these in pretty much all of my projects.   
The first is a sturdy shroud that attaches between a stepper and a perpendicular plane. It was originally designed to replace the flimsy stand-off mounting on my CTC/Flashforge 3D printer. But this one is also handy for hanging a stepper motor for example in a CoreXY stage. It is 25mm high which clears the 24mm shaft of a standard Nema17 stepper and provides plenty of room for a belt to pass through. Beefy and strong. Use M3 x 30mm+ bolts.  
The other bracket is a minimal mount for your stepper. This one mounts on the front or the rear (or both for added strength.) These are not for high-torque applications but great for lighter jobs where you want to mount the stepper parallel to a flat plane such as in an XY stage.

description.text:
I wanted a tyre that would serve well on winter and summertime, and after some testing I have come to this design. It is durable enough to withstand some rock impacts, and also it has enough surface on the outside to stand well against mechanical abrasion.
The grip I get out of these wheels is great!
It fits on the standard 1:10 RC torque transfer nuts (12 mm), and has a hole for 4 mm shaft.

• Print two of both wheel types, flat side down. I have found 0.2 mm layer height and 0.5 infill to work great. I recommend ABS plastic. Support is not needed, but it might help with printing the mounting nut recess.
  • Mount scoop facing the driving direction so that it grips whatever gets under the tyres.
  • Have fun!

title: Four Mirror One puzzle by Osanori Yamamoto

description.text:
This is a fantastic puzzle!
It's not too easy, nor is it too hard to solve. It comes from the mind of a brilliant Japanese puzzle inventor called Osanori Yamamoto, whose Bisect Cube puzzle was one of the first things I uploaded to Thingiverse.
Not only are all his designs very clever puzzles, but many of them are also ideally suited to 3D printing as they require no additional support.
The puzzle consists of one ring shaped piece and four identical T pieces. These must be assembled with the Ts arranged in a mirrored pairing as shown in the photo.
The design was downloaded from the Puzzle Will be Played website at http://www.puzzlewillbeplayed.com/643Ring/FourMirrorOne/

As usual, I have created the STL files with a small bevel (to remove sharp edges which can snag during movement) and a 0.1 mm offset (to give the pieces room to move). Each unit cube is 8 mm on a side but feel free to scale the puzzle up or down in size as you wish.
Do bear in mind however that the fit will get looser as the puzzle gets larger, and tighter if you print a smaller copy.
Print one of the ring pieces (S1) in one colour and four of the T pieces (S2) in a different colour. I prefer a medium infill and 0.2 mm layer height to ensure a nice smooth top surface.

title: Custom Taz X Ends and X Carriage based off Lulzbot Mini

description.text:
I customized the Lulzbot Mini X Ends and X Carriage so it would fit on the Taz. There's also new Z Motor Mounts and Z Tops that Lulzbot designed that need to be printed to be able to use these X Ends. If you try to use this X Ends without the Z Components listed here the X Stepper Motor won't fit because the extrusion is in the way. The current Lulzbot Taz X Carriage will work with these X Ends. I also designed a upper double bearing holder for the Taz X Carriage. It incorporates the cable chain mount and the same wiring scheme as the Mini's. I haven't had a chance to test it out yet but it will allow you to use the taz x carriage and a cable chain.
Some parts like the X Carriage Cover, Belt Mount and Extruder Mount can be downloaded from the Lulzbot website: http://devel.lulzbot.com/Easy_TAZ_Mini/daffodil/production_parts/printed_parts/

remixed_from.title: Coin battery backpack - No soldering needed

description.text: Remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:79502. Tweaked to have a smaller footprint. This is a nice cheap battery holder to use for small projects and prototyping. Wires to your project just go into the holes on the front and back of the holder and are press fit in place when you insert the battery. No soldering, no hassle. ~$.03 to $.05 in material costs.

Strip at lease half an inch of wire to expose the contacts for the battery. For the back half, insert the wire from behind through one of the holes, run it along the channel guide and back out the other end. Clip off excess. Repeat the process for the front using the notches and channel guide there. Insert CR2032. The fit should be snug and the wires will be held in place. See more detailed instructions and pictures here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:79502

I need to hang a large wooden dowel in my closet to hold onto all my hangers.
This thing is a Pole Socket.  It comes in a matched set.  One side is a closed socket, and the other side is half closed.  This allows you to mount them on opposite walls, slide the pole into the closed one,and drop it into the half open holder on the other side.
There's a counter sunk hole in the center of each so a nice flat head screw can nestle in there and not get in the way.
I do want to add some little support, or rounding, or something to the outside of the socket so it is more stable in practice.

1) Print a set, for as many poles as you need to mount
2) Fit a flat head screw (roughly 4mm) in the middle and fasten it to your wall
3) Fit the pole into one side, and then drop it on top of the opening in the other.
4) Rejoice!

description.text: A super thin 1mm shell Guiro that you play by dragging a biro over the ridges while holding it by the built in solid handle

Tricky to make well.  This is my third attempt and the photos show the delaminating on the first two attempts.  Printed in PLA at 185C, you need to have excellent layer registration to print this well.  The hole in the end is to let the amplified sound out with the hollow rigid body acting as a sounding box.
I built in fillets into the design to make the handle stronger and any stress o nit would be less likely to tear the 1mm walls of the main body.  Rounded teeth would give a different sound, as would adjusting the internal cavity to have some support parts to help the top surface hold up
Full size it is 90 mm long to get the 1mm walls out of this STL file
I will be improving this to get a louder sound by building in a shaped sound chamber
For my Printrbot Jr its a long stretch to put the top surface in and there is some stringing inside and a few long thin holes on the surface but overall its printed well
Other ideas at www.ajbooker.co.uk

This is a prototype of a Rostock Delta Arm for testing purposes only.

remixed_from.title: Remix: Deluxe Spool-Holder for XYZ DaVinci

title: Remix: Deluxe spool holder for XYZPrinting DaVinci, no cutting, all printed parts

description.text:
I really like the design of the delux spool holder. I found that sideways holders end up causing jams when the spool starts to run low, because the filament has to bend over the spool wall at pretty extreme angles. However, the delux spool holder requires either removing the top cover or cutting it. I've redesigned the hook attachment so it can be used without removing the top cover. You have to push the cover upwards first - that will give you access to the back wall (see pictures). Then just hang it like it's shown in the picture. Once you have the spool hanging on the holder and the filament threaded through the guide, you can push the back cover back down - there should be enough clearance for the filament and the hangers.
I made the axle small so it can accomodate spools with smaller hub holes - as long as the diameter is under 15mm, it should work.

I printed the hanger and the crosspiece with 20% infill, no support, 40mm/sec. The dovetail connectors are a very tight fit, but they do fit - they did on mine. If you end up using the axle, you need to print it with supports. I recommend printing it horizontally - printing it vertically would have printed layers stressed by the weight of the spool. I sliced it with Cura, since Cura's supports are easier to break off than slic3r's.

It fits directly on to the axis and works for spools from 34 up to 55 mm (inner diameter) but you can easily adjust the max diameter if you want to use larger spools.

A case for a small RPi based home theater. There is room for improvement. It is good enough to put to use.
The case in full (Pi Box 1.19), printed as a whole, took +8 hrs on my Mendel. Hence, it is now composed of distinct faces (Pi Box 1.22). On avarage, each face prints within one to two hours. For the buttons assembly, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:198205 Components:
RPi B
WiFi TL-WN725N
PiFace CAD http://www.piface.org.uk/products/piface_control_and_display
HiFiBerry board https://www.hifiberry.com/dacplus
USB Harddisk 500GB
USB hub
RPi power cable: mini USB left angle to USB
Harddrive cable: USB 3.0 left angle to USB
USB Hub cable: USB 2.0 right angle to mini USB The design was made with FreeCAD http://www.freecadweb.org The dimensions were restricted by the room available in my audio-visual equipment cabinet. No golden ratio there :-)

Not satisfied with the design yet. Following the Cult of Done Manifesto, it is good enough to be put to use.
After printing and cleaning threaded the side columns with M2.5. The bottom plate is screwed on the side columns with M2.5 bolts. The HD mount parts (you need to print four of these) also threaded with M2.5 and assembled into position using the slits in the bottomplate. The divider plate RPi mount holes are drilled with 2.5mm drill, then threaded M3. You have the FreeCAD design file, feel free to adjust or beautify the design to your liking. [2015-03-01 Update] Adjusted the Audio/HDMI and Ethernet holes position. Added SD Card access.
[2015-03-23 Update] Ethernet cutout to make room for USB Hub connector. Clips added to front and back panel.
Fixing collar for generic applications.

description.text:
1930s Chevy style hotrod in both pickup and sedan styles  
Now fixed offroad tyres and missing door on pickup and added skp file

The Sketchup models are full size so you can scale however you like, the photos are 1:24th printings with steampunk engines made from junk.  There are plenty of model engines out there if you want something more conventional.  You should able be able to mix and match between the two vehicles.  I'd recomment printing the peices out seperately and then assembling but I include a mostly complete model if you prefer.
The tops of the windows are delicate so be careful when cleaning around them.  Otherwise it was just a case of printing the parts, attaching the chassis parts to the body, assembling the axles, painting, assembling the cab interior, glazing, wheels and roof last.  
If you cut the front axles carefully you can use some wire to make a pivot and make the steering turn.  Both vehicles in the photos have this done to them.  
The doors are made with front and rear hinges so you can have normal or suicide style doors.  You might even be able to make them work but in 1:24th the hinges are too brittle,  
The wires between the radiator and bulkhead are just painted wire but are typical of the real ones and provide strength to the radiator just like the real ones do.  
Details and engines are not included and made from spare parts,   I should have taken photos before painting and engine installation but I forgot!  
Printed in 1:24th, should print bigger with no problems but don't think they will go a lot smaller, I couldn't get them to print in 1:48th!

There aren't too many places that you actually put a hook on an exterior corner of a wall, but the partition wall for my kitchen is one such. To replace the prototype (a block of wood with nails in) I drafted this item, partly done as a test for the UP! Printer.
Make, line with powerful double-sided tape, splat onto clean wall with - and this is important - the prongs facing upwards.
I've added a stem to use when you don't have 3mm filament.  One side is a bit flatter to make it print more nicely.

You'll also have to make adjustments to the firmware and wire up a connector to use with the current wiring on the Mini.

There are a ton of Raspberry Pi cases already, but I needed a simple mounting option for a robotics project.  This model just has the minimum that I can epoxy onto any other carrier, and screw down to the board.  It has two hollow standoffs that match the two mounting holes on Second Revision Model B (and Model A) boards, and has two other standoffs that should not interfere with underside components.

Print the Berry Simple Pi Tray.  Attach the tray to a cabinet wall or other project surface, by clipping, nailing, gluing or whatever means.
I was thinking of including specific nail holes or extra pegs on the outside edge, but any such extras would be particular to the project at hand.  This is a starting point for making minimal mount options for the Raspberry Pi.  Deriving a new mount from this model should be easy in any STL editor.

CASTELLANO-------------------------------------------------
Mi primer diseño en Thingiverse. Necesitaba algo que me ayudase a transportar los botes de pintura de Tamiya de forma ordenada cuando llevo el equipo fuera de casa.
Como se puede ver en las imágenes, en cada caja caben 6 botes de pintura.
La base tiene huecos en la base que encajan con los tapones de los botes para que se puedan apilar uno encima de otro. ENGLISH--------------------------------------------
My first design in Thingiverse. I needed something that helps me to carry Tamiya paint cans in an orderly manner when I took the equipment out from home.
As you can see in the images, in each case fit 6 cans of paint.
The base has holes at the base that match the plugs of the boats so you can stack one above the other.

Poseidon's realm not your thing when it comes to office supplies? Then harness the almighty power of Mother Nature to cut your tape. These vines are meant to grow out of your wall (be it apartment or cubicle) but may need some help with a few well-placed thumbtacks. ~Thanks to stateofkate for suggesting vines as being a potential tape-cutting entity~
  • Now with a screw holes included option

-Single.stl is for my single-extrusion peeps.
-Part1 & -Part2.stl are for when you want your flower to be a different color than your vines. Like Tentacle Tape Dispenser (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:652386), this is a great use for one of your old x-acto blades. But if you don't want to risk slicing a finger open, you could print out TapeBlade.stl for a sweet serrated cutting blade. .Thing is the MakerWare file all set up for dual extrusion .mix is the "final" version in Meshmixer before I cut everything up and export them as .STLs

author: sharkbot

description.text: This is my OpenSCAD design to generate a table saw rail guide. I have tried to parameterize almost every aspect of the design so that you can create just about any table saw rail guide as long as you can input the dimensions into the OpenSCAD file. Particularly, the STL file I've uploaded works perfectly for my Craftsman portable table saw. I'm using the guides that I printed on a featherboard with screws and adjustable knobs that when tightened will cause the rail guide to expand and prevent slippage. Most of the dimensions for my print are done with a 0.4mm clearance (0.2mm per side) on my Robo 3D, which worked perfectly. This will vary from printer to printer, so don't get frustrated if your first print is a little too large or small to fit your guide, it takes a very small amount of plastic. Also, i'd like to attribute jacksonliam for providing his rCube module at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8812/#comment-380315

An Air Jordan keychain. I took the Air Jordan logo, extruded it, and added a keychain hole right where the basketball is.  
Enjoy!

Double Reed Players Rejoice! Now there's no need to kick the water cup down when you need to soak your reed in orchestra rehearsal. This part slides on the lip of the music stand, keeping out of a foot's path, as well as in easy reach. The edge is beveled so it hardly affects the ability to flip sheet music. The water cup is 32mm in diamteter. There's also a hole to place a pencil for easy access. The difference between versions 1 and 3 are the holes. The holes are to prevent warping of the build plate (if printing in ABS). Credit to J Mantzel who gave me the idea to add holes to the part. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YhfrHo53K18
Print as it is oriented when uploaded. This eliminates the need for support material.

Finally! A cacodemon that we can print! This has been one of my favorite monsters from DOOM and DOOM II for a long time and I am glad that I am able to print one now! I printed mine in traslucent red so it is hard to see in the light.

title: Bathtub U-Boat Improved Stand w/Corrected Class/Hull

description.text: One of my FAVORITE models of all time is The Bathtub U-boat by Skimbal http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6432 The file 'substandcupLS' is my final version. The 'substandcup' is a basic blocky version for editing. I have printed it numerous times including once at 2x scale (64" long) I wanted a better stand. Not only that but the hull number listed U-522 was for a IX class boat. The class listed for it is correct as this IS a class VII/C. There was no 622 but there WAS a 722 hull built. I've changed it so it reflects that.
I drew this in Cubify Design to be sliced by Simplify3D and printed in my Craftbot at the usual medium resolution settings with NO raft or supports.

comments.text: when you print the sub, did u use any supports?
comments.author: 368printer

comments.text: Nope. I print it in PLA on both an unheated (Replicator 2) and a heated (Davinci) printer. I've also printed most of the hull on a delta Orion but the conning tower wouldn't fit (and I lost interest). The guns and periscopes can be tricky...but with careful gluing and sanding theycome out too.
comments.author: 368printer
